#Text=Chapter 24
#Text=Sometimes lolling upon Tantor 's back , sometimes roaming the jungle in solitude , Korak made his way slowly toward the West and South .
#Text=He made but a few miles a day , for he had a whole lifetime before him and no place in particular to go .

#Text=Possibly he would have moved more rapidly but for the thought which continually haunted him that each mile he traversed carried him further and further away from Meriem -- no longer his Meriem , as of yore , it is true !
#Text=but still as dear to him as ever .
#Text=Thus he came upon the trail of The Sheik 's band as it traveled down river from the point where The Sheik had captured Meriem to his own stockaded village .
#Text=Korak pretty well knew who it was that had passed , for there were few in the great jungle with whom he was not familiar , though it had been years since he had come this far north .

#Text=He had no particular business , however , with the old Sheik and so he did not propose following him -- the further from men he could stay the better pleased he would be -- he wished that he might never see a human face again .
#Text=Men always brought him sorrow and misery .
#Text=The river suggested fishing and so he dawdled upon its shores , catching fish after a fashion of his own devising and eating them raw .
#Text=When night came he curled up in a great tree beside the stream -- the one from which he had been fishing during the afternoon -- and was soon asleep .
#Text=Numa , roaring beneath him , awoke him .
#Text=He was about to call out in anger to his noisy neighbor when something else caught his attention .
#Text=He listened .
#Text=Was there something in the tree beside himself ?
#Text=Yes , he heard the noise of something below him trying to clamber upward .
#Text=Presently he heard the click of a crocodile 's jaws in the waters beneath , and then , low but distinct : " By George !

#Text=Korak shouted down at him , calling him , in the language of the great apes ,  Old green-eyed eater of carrion , " " Brother of Dango , " the hyena , and other choice appellations of jungle opprobrium .

column1: #Text=The Hon. Morison Baynes , listening , felt assured that a gorilla had seized upon him .
#Text=He felt for his revolver , and as he was drawing it stealthily from its holster a voice asked in perfectly good English , " Who are you ? "
#Text=Baynes started so that he nearly fell from the branch .
#Text=" My God ! " he exclaimed .
#Text=" Are you a man ? "
#Text=" What did you think I was ? " asked Korak .
#Text=" A gorilla , " replied Baynes , honestly .
#Text=Korak laughed .
#Text=" Who are you ? " he repeated .
#Text=" I 'm an Englishman by the name of Baynes ; but who the devil are you ? " asked the Hon. Morison .
#Text=" They call me The Killer , " replied Korak , giving the English translation of the name that Akut had given him .

#Text=And then after a pause during which the Hon. Morison attempted to pierce the darkness and catch a glimpse of the features of the strange being into whose hands he had fallen , " You are the same whom I saw kissing the girl at the edge of the great plain to the East , that time that the lion charged you ? "
#Text=" Yes , " replied Baynes .
#Text=" What are you doing here ? "
#Text=" The girl was stolen -- I am trying to rescue her . "
#Text=" Stolen ! "
#Text=The word was shot out like a bullet from a gun .
#Text=" Who stole her ? "
#Text=" The Swede trader , Hanson , " replied Baynes .
#Text=" Where is he ? "
#Text=Baynes related to Korak all that had transpired since he had come upon Hanson 's camp .
#Text=Before he was done the first gray dawn had relieved the darkness .
#Text=Korak made the Englishman comfortable in the tree .
#Text=He filled his canteen from the river and fetched him fruits to eat .
#Text=Then he bid him good-bye .
#Text=" I am going to the Swede 's camp , " he announced .
#Text=" I will bring the girl back to you here . "
#Text=" I shall go , too , then , " insisted Baynes .
#Text=" It is my right and my duty , for she was to have become my wife . "
#Text=Korak winced .
#Text=" You are wounded .

#Text= I can go much faster alone . "

column1: #Text=" Go , then , " replied Baynes ; " but I shall follow .

column3:
_	_	_	_

#Text= As you will , " replied Korak , with a shrug .

column1: #Text=If the man wanted to be killed it was none of his affair .
#Text=He wanted to kill him himself , but for Meriem 's sake he would not .
#Text=If she loved him then he must do what he could to preserve him , but he could not prevent his following him , more than to advise him against it , and this he did , earnestly .
